title-group.article-title: Factors influencing the survival of implant-supported ceramic-ceramic prostheses: A randomized, controlled clinical trial

article-meta.aff: aDivision of Prosthodontics, Restorative Dental Sciences, University of Florida College of Dentistry, Gainesville, FL, United States
bDepartment of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Florida Herbert Wertheim College of Engineering, Gainesville, FL, United States
cDental Clinical Research Unit, University of Florida College of Dentistry Office of Research, Gainesville, FL, United States

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author at: University of Florida College of Dentistry, 1395 Center Drive, Rm D9-6, Gainesville, FL 32610, United States. jesquivel@dental.ufl.edu (J.F. Esquivel-Upshaw).

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/BY-NC-ND/4.0/).

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: The goals of this research are: (1) to determine the clinical survival of ceramic-ceramic 3-unit implant supported fixed dental prostheses (FDPs) compared with control metal-ceramic and; (2) to analyze the effects of design parameters such as connector height, radius of curvature of gingival embrasure, and occlusal veneer thickness.

sec.title: Materials and Methods:
sec.p: This randomized, controlled clinical trial enrolled 96 participants with 129 3-unit implant-supported FDPs. Participants were randomized to receive different design combinations to include FDP material, thickness of occlusal veneer ceramic, radius of curvature of gingival embrasure and connector height. Participants were recalled for 6 months, 1 year and yearly thereafter for the next 5 years. FDPs were examined for evidence of fracture and radiographs were made to assess viability of implants. Fractographic analyses and Kaplan Meier survival analysis was used to analyze the data.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: 27 FDPs, representing 21%, exhibited chipping fractures of the veneer during the 5-year observation period. There was no statistically significant effect of type of material, veneer thickness, radius of curvature of gingival embrasure and connector height on occurrence of fracture. Fractographic and occlusal analyses reveal that fractures originated from the occlusal surface and that occlusion was the most important factor in determining survival. Stresses calculated at failure demonstrated lower values compared with in vitro data.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Implant-supported ceramic-ceramic prosthesis is a viable alternative to metal-ceramic. Survival analysis for both materials were comparable and design parameters employed in this study did not affect survival as long as zirconia was used as the core material.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: More technical complications and lower success rates have been observed with all-ceramic prostheses compared with metal-ceramic ones primarily because of the physical properties of ceramics. Clinical survival levels for metal-ceramic fixed dental prostheses (FDPs) have been documented for up to 15 years with a success rate of 74–85% [1–3]. FDPs have a complicated architecture in that there is tension and compression that occurs on different parts of the restoration during mastication so that FDP survival can decrease to 87% at 10 years and 69% at 15 years when broader definitions of failure are applied. Based on systematic reviews comparing clinical survival rates of FDPs for 5-years, all-ceramic FDPs have significantly lower survival rates at 86–90.4% than metal-ceramic FDPs with 94.4 [4,5]. Longer term survival rates for all-ceramic FDPs demonstrate a larger difference in clinical survival with metal-ceramic FDPs with reported cumulative survival rates at 29.5% for fixed to fixed abutment and 22.5% for cantilevers for 13 years [6]. A similar study reports survival at 48.6% and success at 30.9% for 15 years using lithia disilicate ceramics [7].

Dental implants are steadily becoming the treatment of choice for the replacement of missing teeth. However, when used to support bridges, these implant-supported FDPs become a bar structure with tension and high stress concentrations along the gingival area. In the absence of a periodontal ligament to reduce shear stress and strain and minimize the impact of high occlusal forces, the implication for brittle materials could be catastrophic. However, an in vitro study [8] concluded that implant-supported ceramic prostheses fractured at higher loads than those supported by natural teeth. Meta-analysis studies show that the cumulative success rates for implant-supported metal-ceramic FDPs are 95.2% for 5 years and 86.7% for 10 years [9] compared with conventional tooth-supported FDPs have survival levels of 93.8%. Another systematic review recommended against the use of conventional veneered zirconia for implant-supported prosthesis [10]. This study reported a survival of 98.7% for metal-ceramic implant supported prostheses versus 93% for zirconia-ceramic implant supported prosthesis. This study further details the fractures associated with metal-ceramic are 11.6% compared with 50% for zirconia ceramic. This translated to a loss of 4.1% of the zirconia ceramic prosthesis compared with only 0.2% of the metal-ceramic resulting from fractures.

The susceptibility of ceramic-ceramic prosthesis to higher failure rates have led to in vitro studies documenting possible design parameters which could influence failure. As a result of very limited clinical evidence, dentists and laboratory technicians mainly depend on these in vitro results along with manufacturer recommendations. The following design parameters demonstrated an effect on fracture susceptibility of ceramic-ceramic prostheses.

sec.title: Effect of type of material
sec.p: Zirconia has been shown to be the strongest ceramic used for dental prostheses with a demonstrated long term reliability, 0% failure probability after 10 years of static loading [11] and a high resistance to subcritical crack growth [12]. This is significant because studies have shown the failure rate for ceramic-ceramic restorations is twice as high as metal-ceramic ones [13] Limited clinical studies have demonstrated that the failure rate for zirconia frameworks is 0 to 0.48% compared with other ceramic materials at 1.88–4.24% [13] after one year. Additionally, the 5-year survival of ceramic frameworks is 6.5% and was more evident for In-Ceram Alumina, In-Ceram Zirconia and glass-ceramic FDPs than Y-TZP (Yttria-Stabilized Tetragonal Zirconia Polycrystal) Zirconia [4]. Therefore, use of zirconia cores is warranted in high stress and load situations such as implant-supported FDPs.

sec.title: Effect of connector
sec.p: FDP connectors are the thinnest and weakest part of the core structure and have demonstrated to have the highest concentration of stress. Failure rates of 10–12% after 5 years for earlier clinical studies on lithia-disilicate-based glass-ceramic and glass-infiltrated alumina [14–18] have been attributed to failure along the connectors. A comparison of connector diameters from 3 to 4 mm demonstrated a 40%–50% reduction in stress with the increased dimension [19]. The connector height, shape and span of edentulous area greatly influence the amount of stress on the restoration and are critical to prosthesis survival [11,20,21].

sec.title: Effect of curvature of gingival embrasure
sec.p: The curvature of gingival embrasure has also been shown to influence the fracture resistance of all-ceramic FDPs with acute radii increasing stress and acting as sites of fracture initiation [22,23]. The fracture resistance of a prosthesis doubled with a change in radius from 0.25 to 0.90 mm. Y-TZP frameworks demonstrated a 20% increase in fracture strength, with an increase in radius from 0.6 to 0.9 mm [24].

sec.title: Effect of veneer thickness
sec.p: The core-veneer ratio is also critical to provide adequate thickness of the veneer. However, an ideal ratio should be determined because adequate bulk is necessary but increased thickness of the veneering porcelain have been associated with cracking, faster cooling rates, and thermal incompatibility of the two ceramic layers [25,26]. An in vitro analysis of different core/veneer thickness ratios demonstrated that a decrease in the core thickness from 0.8 to 0.4 mm, with a total thickness of 1.6 mm, doubles the fracture probability at 1, 5, and 10 years with vertical loading [27]. Additionally, changing the load orientation from 90° to 70° increases fracture by 79.4% in 10 years. They concluded that a lower core/veneer ratio has a higher fracture probability and stresses increase in the core with a 70° load orientation

The goals of this research are: (1) to determine the clinical survival of ceramic-ceramic 3-unit implant supported FDPs compared with control metal-ceramic FDPs and; (2) to analyze the effects of variable design parameters such as connector height, radius of curvature of gingival embrasure, and occlusal veneer thickness. The following hypotheses were tested in vivo to achieve these goals: (1) test the hypothesis that posterior yttria-stabilized zirconia-core, three-unit implant-supported fixed partial dentures (FDPs) will withstand occlusal forces when the core thickness is as low as 0.5 mm; (2) test the hypothesis that the fracture probability of posterior three-unit, implant-supported zirconia-based FDPs increases as the thickness ratio of veneering ceramic to core ceramic increases; (3) test the hypothesis that a minimum connector height of 3 mm and a minimum radius of curvature of 0.25 mm at the gingival embrasure of a three-unit implant supported FDP based on an yttria-stabilized zirconia core ceramic are necessary to resist fracture under occlusal loading.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: The protocol for this study was described in a previous article [28]. For convenience, the methods will be summarized briefly.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: Institutional Review Board approval was obtained for human subject trials. This prospective, randomized, controlled, single-blind clinical trial involved participants needing 3-unit implant supported FDPs to replace teeth in the posterior area of the mouth. The participants were randomly assigned, using a random number table, generated by a statistician, to receive either a metal-ceramic or a ceramic-ceramic implant-supported FDP. These were further subdivided into different design parameters for veneer ceramic thickness, connector radius of curvature, and connector height (Fig. 1, Table 1). Power analysis was conducted prior to initiating the study to detect a survival difference of 15 percentage points between metal-ceramic and all-ceramic FDPs. N = 60 subjects per group were needed to deliver 80% power to detect such a difference and determined a sample size of 120 participants.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: Participants were recruited and selected based on the following criteria: (1) 21–75 years, and no contraindications to dental treatment; (2) no active caries, no periodontal disease, and no periodontal pocket depths greater than 4 mm; (3) missing at least three teeth in the posterior area; (4) Natural teeth opposing the edentulous area; (5) adequate bone height and width and interoccusal distance at areas of proposed implant sites; (6) good oral hygiene; (8) compliance with appointments. Eligible participants were consented and assigned to interventions by the Dental Clinical Research Unit Clinical Coordinator. Participants were not made aware of their allocation.

sec.title: Study intervention
sec.p: Participants were evaluated for bone height and width through computerized tomography. Two implants (Titanium metal, grit blasted with titanium dioxide and fluoride particles, OsseoSpeed, Astra Tech Implant System, Dentsply Sirona Implants, Mölndal, Sweden) were placed using a surgical guide. Final impressions were made with vinylpolysiloxane impression material (VPS, Aquasil, Dentsply Caulk) after eight weeks of healing. Type IV stone (Die-Keen, Whip Mix Corp) and soft tissue material (Gingitech, Ivoclar Vivadent, Schaan) were used for casts. Custom abutments (Gold shaded custom milled titanium abutments, Atlantis Abutments, Waltham, USA) were fabricated to ensure 2 mm interocclusal clearance for the FDP material. For ceramic-ceramic (CC) FDPs (Yttria-stabilized zirconia core, pressable fluorapatite glass ceramic, IPS e.max ZirCAD and ZirPress, Ivoclar Vivadent, Schaan, Liechtenstein) core substructures were designed and milled (InEOS, Sirona), followed by veneer pressing. For metal-ceramic FDPs (Noble Pd-Au-Ag alloy (Capricorn, Ivoclar, Vivadent/press-on leucite reinforced glass ceramic veneer IPS InLine POM, Ivoclar Vivadent, Schaan, Liechtenstein) metal substructures were cast and veneered. Occlusal adjustments were made with an ultra-fine grit diamond bur (Brassler, USA) and polished with abrasive wheels and diamond paste. FDPs were cemented with a resin cement (RelyX Unicem Self-Adhesive Universal Resin Cement, 3M ESPE). Occlusion was adjusted to have light contact with an 8-micron shimstock (Shimstock Occlusion Foil, Almore, USA) barely sliding through. After cementation, occlusal markings in maximum intercuspation (MI) and excursive movements were observed and photographed for baseline records. VPS impressions were made of each quadrant to serve as baseline.

sec.title: Post cementation analysis
sec.p: Participants were recalled at 6 months, 1 year and yearly thereafter for 5 years. Participants were immediately recalled before the designated recall time if they perceived a possibility of fracture. VPS impressions were made of each quadrant at each recall visit and photographs were taken of occlusal markings at MI (red) and excursive movements (black). If a fracture was noted clinically, FDP surfaces were cleaned with a water spray, rinsed with ethanol and air-dried. This procedure was repeated twice. A VPS impression of each fracture surface was made twice to fabricate acrylic replicates for fractographic analysis. Fractures were examined and details of the fracture recorded [29]. Fractures were classified as (1) Class I, minor or no intervention required; (2) Class 2, repair needed; (3) Class 3, replacement required [30].

Replicates of the fractured FDPs were examined under SEM to determine the origin of fracture and to calculate the stress at fracture from formula 1a and 1b below. The relationship between the stress at fracture, or strength, σf, and the fracture toughness, KIC, is: (1a)KIC=Yσf(c1/2)=√(2Eγc) (1b)σf=KIC/[Y(c1/2)] where KIC is the critical stress intensity factor (fracture toughness) and Y is a geometric factor which accounts for the shape of the fracture-initiating crack, E is the elastic (Young’s) modulus, c is the crack size, and γc is the critical fracture energy, i.e., all the energy involved in fracture including the creation of new surface.

The study was powered to detect a difference in survival rate between material groups of 15 percentage points or more using a log-rank test. Kaplan-Meier methods were used to compare long-term survival among the types of FDP, veneer thickness, diameter and connector height, with each factor analyzed separately because of the limitations of our sample size. We also used Kaplan Meier methods to compare the 6 possible combinations each of material type and veneer thickness, material type and diameter of embrasure, and material type and connector height. All analyses were performed using the “survival” package in the R statistical software package (V.3.6.1, the R Foundation for Statistical Computing).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 129 FDPs, on 96 participants (no participant having more than two FDPs), were delivered with 65 CC and 64 MC on 42 males and 54 females. Consort diagram detailing patient recruitment and retention is shown in Fig. 2. 27 FDPs exhibited chipping fractures of the veneer during the five-year observation period (11 MC and 16 CC), representing 21% of the study population. All 27 fractures occurred on 27 different participants. Some fractures were so small that they were imperceptible to the participants. The distribution of fractures according to fracture classification are illustrated in Table 2. Clinical images of the different fracture classifications are shown in Fig. 3. The distribution of fractures according to material, veneer thickness, radius of curvature of gingival embrasure and connector height are shown in Table 3. Kaplan-Meier survival analysis showed that there was no statistically significant effect of type of material (log-rank p = 0.21), veneer thickness (p = 0.43), radius of curvature of gingival embrasure (p = 0.52) and connector height (p = 0.89) on the occurrence of fracture. Kaplan Meier analysis revealed the estimated mean time to fracture for all FDPs was 57.5 months (95% CI = 53.0, 62.0) with 59.2 months (CI = 53.5, 64.9) for MC and 54.3 months (CI = 47.7, 60.9) for CC. Mean survival times by veneer thickness were 52.9 months (CI = 45.3, 60.5) for 0.5 mm; 60.4 months (CI = 53.5, 67.5) for 1.0 mm and; 54.6 months (CI 47.6, 61.6) for 1.5 mm. Mean survival times by radius of curvature of gingival embrasure were 52.2 months (CI = 44.9, 59.5) for 0.25 mm; 56.8 months (CI = 48.7, 64.9) for 0.5 mm; and 58.5 months (CI = 51.9, 65.1) for 0.75 mm. Lastly, mean survival times by connector heights were 54.9 months (CI = 46.3, 63.5) for 3 mm; 56.8 months (CI = 49.7, 63.9) for 4 mm and; 57.9 months (CI = 50.7, 65.1) for 5 mm.

The combined analysis revealed no significant difference in survival with type/veneer thickness (p = 0.06) with the following survival times (Fig. 4): (1) MC/0.5, 51.5 months (CI = 42.1, 60.9); (2) MC/1.0, 55.9 months (CI = 45.6, 66.2); (3) MC/1.5 63.5 months (CI = 58.6, 68.4); (4) CC/0.5, 52.2 months (CI = 41.4, 63.0); (5) CC/1.0, 62.5 months (CI = 55.7, 69.3); (6) CC/1.5, 45.6 months (CI = 35.7, 55.5). The survival for the combined analysis of type/radius of curvature of gingival embrasure was also not significant (p = 0.5) as well as the type/connector height (p = 0.7).

Two implants were removed due to bone loss resulting in loss of two prostheses being supported. The overall survival rate (FDPs remaining in the mouth after 5 years) for implant-supported FDPs was 96.8%. The overall success rate (FDPs which remained in original state from cementation), including technical and biological complications was 78%.

Fractographic analysis on all fractured samples revealed that almost all fractures originated from the occlusal surface. Analyses also revealed that stress at fracture for CC was 37 ± 12 MPa, and for MC was 44 ± 12 MPa.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This randomized clinical trial aimed to determine the influence of different design parameters on implant-supported three-unit ceramic-ceramic prostheses. The variables that were tested showed possible associations with fracture of the prosthesis in laboratory trials. There are limited clinical studies that document the survival of implant-supported FDPs [10,31–34]. A systematic review revealed that the cumulative 5-year complication rate for tooth supported FDPs was 27.6% compared with 30.5% for implant supported FDPs [35]. The main causes for failure of tooth supported FDPs were veneer fracture, framework fracture and caries while only veneer fractures were reported for implant-supported FDPs for these studies. The success rate for these clinical studies was 69.5% compared with the success rate of this current study which is 78%.

Veneer fracture on zirconia-based frameworks has been widely documented. Veneered zirconia exhibited chipping failures (56%) at twice the amount of veneered metal at 28% [36]. These findings are consistent with the results from other clinical studies [9,13,37–39], which report numerous chipping failures with ceramic veneered to zirconia. Inadequate prosthesis design, where there is not enough support for the veneer by the framework, is a possible reason for this technical complication with a study reporting that an increase in core thickness significantly improved the reliability of the restoration [40]. The current study demonstrated that the veneer/core thickness ratio had no effect on the fracture susceptibility of the restorations. However, the mean survival time for the 1.0 mm veneer thickness was slightly higher than the 0.5 and 1.5 mm although no significance was reached. If the sample size was greater, there is a possibility that this parameter might reach significance, indicating an ideal thickness for veneers on ceramic cores.

The quality of the porcelain layering can also be a factor where the presence of pores can produce stress concentrations along the restoration. Numerous pores, which are possible areas of stress concentration, were demonstrated on micro-CT images of heat-pressed veneers and CAD-CAM frameworks [41]. However, other studies have shown that pressed veneers demonstrated fewer chipping fractures [36]. Fractographic analysis of fractured samples in this current study revealed that fractures originated from the occlusal surface and no pores were evident where stresses could have concentrated below the surface (Fig. 5). The observed stresses at failure were lower than the derived stress from the manufacturers (110 ± 10 MPa for ZirPress and 130 ± 20 MPa for IPS POM) but this is to be expected. Manufacturers’ obtained strengths are usually from small bars or disks that are highly polished. Therefore, the fracture origins are expected to be smaller than those observed in clinical service leading to greater strength values in vitro.

The coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) or cooling schedule mismatch between the zirconia and veneer has also been named a culprit for veneer chipping. Chipping fractures could be the result of residual tensile stresses which develop from the slow cooling of the zirconia framework with a CTE mismatch [42]. A CTE mismatch can also minimize the bond strength between the veneering porcelain and the zirconia [43]. To offset this mismatch, slow cooling is recommended to minimize the residual stresses that develop in the veneering ceramic although this method has been shown to decrease interfacial strength [44].

Loading orientation intraorally is also a possible cause of veneer chipping. A ceramic restoration is better equipped to accept vertical forces, which produce compressive stresses rather than lateral or oblique forces, which result in tensile stresses. For this cohort, an occlusal analysis was conducted to determine whether a correlation exists between the location of maximum intercuspation and excursive contacts [45]. There was a significant correlation between the presence of maximum intercuspation contacts and the occurrence of fracture (p = 0.004). No correlation exists between the presence of other (excursive) contacts (p = 0.76) and non-supporting cusp contact p = 0.76) with the occurrence of fracture.

Connector dimension was also shown to not have an effect on the fracture susceptibility of these ceramic-ceramic prostheses. Most manufacturers recommend that the connector height be no less than 4 mm as evidenced by numerous fractures which originated from the gingival area of the connectors. However, this study has demonstrated that zirconia cores are strong enough to withstand connector heights as low as 3 mm with acute angles of curvature of gingival embrasure. None of the fractures in this study originated from the connector and none of the connectors fractured.

One limitation of the study is that the clustering effect was not accounted as some patients received more than one FDP. The study was powered to detect a difference between material groups only under the assumption that patient effects could be ignored. The differences between subgroups were presented as data of interest that were observed in detecting a difference between material groups.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The objective of this research was to identify the design parameters which are most likely to control the success or failure of implant-supported ceramic-ceramic prostheses. Within the limitations of the study, occlusion is the single most important factor in determining survival of a veneered all-ceramic FDP. Type of material, connector height and radius of curvature of gingival embrasure had no effect on fracture probability when zirconia ceramics are used as cores. Veneer thickness had no effect on the fracture probability although a 1.0 mm core/veneer thickness ratio might prove to be an ideal thickness with a greater sample size. Fractographic analysis confirmed that almost all fractures originated on the occlusal area within the veneer.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: This study was supported by NIH-NIDCR grant R01 DE025001 and the University of Florida Clinical and Translational Science Institute, which is supported in part by the NIH National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences under award number UL1TR001427. The content is solely the responsibility of the authors and does not necessarily represent the official views of the National Institutes of Health. Ceramic materials were provided by Ivoclar Vivadent and implant materials were provided by Dentsply. This study is registered in Clinical Trials. Gov under study number NCT01729858. The complete protocol can be viewed under this site. There are no conflicts of interest associated with this research project.

fn.p: The authors declare that there are no conflicts of interest associated with this project.

caption.p: Different design parameters tested in this study to include variability in core/veneer thickness ratio, connector height and radius of curvature in gingival embrasure.
Consort diagram showing recruitment and retention distribution of participants.
Clinical images of Class 1–3 fracture classification. Arrows on left clinical images indicate location of fracture and the arrows on the SEM images indicate possible fracture origin.
Kaplan Meier survival table with combined analysis for material type and veneer thickness.
SEM image of fracture originating from the occlusal surface (arge solid arrows) where the pores are shown (small dashed arrows) to have little or no effect on the crack propagation.
Detailed outline of groups and variables included in this study.

tr.th: Radius of Curvature of Gingival Embrasure (mm)

caption.p: Distribution of fracture according to fracture classification.
Distribution of fractures according to the different design variables.

tr.th: Radius of Curvature of Gingival Embrasure (mm) = # of Fractures
